awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in economic theory. In today's markets, essentially all financial assets are traded in multiple trading venues that operate in a decentralized way. The recent financial crisis raised questions about the effects of market fragmentation, the impact of new exchanges, and the possibility of excessive financial innovation, calling for new areas of investigation and modeling. This project has two broad objectives. First, it will identify potential sources of efficiency gains associated with decentralized trading. Second, the project will contribute general principles for financial market design as well as support for policy evaluation and methods that would help develop a theory of imperfectly competitive fragmented markets. The research could help achieve greater efficiency and revenue, while meeting important societal objectives for equality and incentives. The results could also be useful for antitrust regulators and for policy makers and others who seek to evaluate financial regulations. Improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness of financial markets help to create economic prosperity.

This research introduces a flexible framework for the equilibrium analysis of imperfectly competitive financial markets. To the growing literature on decentralized trading, which has explored over-the-counter (bilateral) transactions, this research contributes methods for equilibrium analysis of general market structures with multiple coexisting exchanges and flexible contracts. The research team will examine three classes of instruments that would be redundant if trading were either competitive or centralized: (1) the creation of new trading venues for existing assets and exchange design, (2) the introduction of new assets, and (3) innovation in the types of market clearing that decentralized trading enables. The results will demonstrate the greater potential of market design to increase efficiency relative to centralized trading. As classical methods for equilibrium analysis, which are based on spanning, do not apply in (imperfectly competitive) decentralized markets, this research will develop an alternative approach. The techniques developed in this project may be used by others to facilitate research on complex networks. Broader impacts include the possible effects on market practice and government policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Financial markets are comprised of many coexisting trading venues. Traders often participate in multiple exchanges for the same assets. Fragmentation is a characteristic of virtually any asset class, including stocks, bonds, interbank loans, and asset-backed securities.

This research has two broad objectives. The first is to understand economic mechanisms that arise in decentralized—but not centralized—markets to uncover potential sources of efficiency gains associated with both decentralized and centralized trading. The second objective is to contribute methods that would enrich equilibrium analysis of imperfectly competitive decentralized markets and help to advance a new area of decentralized-market design of direct practical and policy relevance.

Accordingly, this research makes two methodological contributions: First, it introduces a flexible framework for decentralized markets with general market structures and rich contracts for any number of strategic agents and assets. The framework allows a systematic analysis of centralized and decentralized markets, while allowing an explicit treatment of price impact. Many financial markets are dominated by large institutional investors whose behavior impacts prices; indeed, in practice, dealing with strategic behavior (price impact) is often the primary motivation for creating an alternative exchange or introducing a new financial product.

Further, accounting for the endogeneity of the market structure is critical for evaluating the effects of changes to market structure or market design. A study of endogenous market structures requires the accommodation of general externalities and multilateral “contracts,” which has been challenging. As its second methodological contribution, this work introduces matching-based tools for the analysis of markets with externalities and multilateral contracts, where the empirical literature has created demand for new methods.

According to the standard theory based on centralized trading, the introduction of securities whose payoff span is neutral to the span of the traded assets is neutral to traders’ payoffs; diversification and risk sharing do not depend on the asset structure, only on the asset span.

A key finding of this research is that when traders have price impact, standard results and methods for equilibrium analysis, which are based on spanning, do not apply. The general failure of spanning in decentralized markets motivates several types of financial innovation that would be neutral for equilibrium if trading were centralized, such as derivatives, exchange-traded products (ETPs), exchange-traded funds (ETFs), types of bespoke financial products created for institutional investors, and other financial instruments whose rate of innovation and trading activity continue to be high. It also identifies opportunities for new market-clearing technologies, including priority in market clearing across assets, joint vs. separate clearing of assets, the introduction of new exchanges, exchange mergers, and inclusions of new assets.

This research also evaluates several policy-motivated designs---implemented or proposed. They include the update to the US RegNMS and the European consolidation tape in equity markets, privacy-preserving regulation, and innovation in multi-asset market technology exchange providers have experimented with. The results illuminate which type of investment in multi-asset market-clearing technology is efficient and establish when the welfare effects of introducing new products, such as derivatives, differ from those of new market-clearing technologies. Asset innovation and exchange design generally serve as separate instruments in decentralized-market design and should be regulated jointly.

Missing markets and the resulting exposure to systemic risk have been central to recent dis- cussions of the 2008 financial crisis. In order to monitor financial innovation, the Security and Exchange Commission (SEC) in September 2009 created the Division of Risk, Strategy and Financial Innovation, the first new division created by the SEC in 37 years. The proposed project provides tools to identify and assess the efficiency benefits and costs associated with missing markets.

In particular, derivatives markets are often seen by regulators as particularly challenging. This is due, among other factors, to the difficulty of assessing the scope for innovating nonredundant derivatives or their efficiency benefits—in the standard theory of asset pricing, derivatives are priced assuming the existence of a replicating portfolio, i.e., assuming that derivatives are redundant. By providing an equilibrium model of nonredundant derivatives, this project can help guide the regulation of various types of derivatives markets.

The results of this research also qualify the design recommendation for package/combinatorial design for markets with multi-unit valuations (Spectrum, Treasury bills, electricity, emission permits), which have largely developed for markets whose participants have unit valuations. Specifically, in markets with multi-unit valuations, combinatorial design isn't generally efficient even when bidders' demands exhibit complementarities.

More generally, this research takes a step toward developing the principles of decentralized market design.
